title: Effects of episodic low aragonite saturation and elevated temperature on the physiology of Stylophora pistillata
abstract: As global climate change is predicted to gradually alter the oceans' carbonate system and water temperature, knowledge about the effects an altered marine environment has on the physiology of reef building (hermatypic) coral species is more widely established. However, although it is recognized that seawater temperature and the carbonate system of a coral reef can change rapidly and with great amplitude, little is known about how the interaction of these natural fluctuations with long term effects of climate change may affect the metabolism and productivity of hermatypic corals. To investigate this, we acclimated the hermatypic coral Stylophora pistillata to a "worst case" scenario for carbon dioxide emissions (aragonite saturation state [Ω ARAG ] = 1.6), and tested how exposure to short term (24 h) elevated temperature (+3°C) and further lowered Ω ARAG (−1 unit) affected its photosynthesis and respiration. While episodic exposure to very low Ω ARAG had only little effect on S. pistillata's physiology, short term heat stress caused a shift from net oxygen production to consumption and partial coral bleaching. Higher gross coral respiration, and lowered photosynthetic activity under episodically elevated temperature may have been the result of photoinhibition and partial coral bleaching. These findings suggest that fluctuating environmental conditions in combination with a low Ω ARAG background signal may impair basic metabolic processes in calcifying corals. In a future high-CO world short term stress could be relevant for reef ecosystem processes, and may affect the resilience of coral reefs to other external influences and effects of climate change.

abstract.text: As global climate change is predicted to gradually alter the oceans' carbonate system and water temperature, knowledge about the effects an altered marine environment has on the physiology of reef building (hermatypic) coral species is more widely established. However, although it is recognized that seawater temperature and the carbonate system of a coral reef can change rapidly and with great amplitude, little is known about how the interaction of these natural fluctuations with long term effects of climate change may affect the metabolism and productivity of hermatypic corals. To investigate this, we acclimated the hermatypic coral Stylophora pistillata to a "worst case" scenario for carbon dioxide emissions (aragonite saturation state [Ω ARAG ] = 1.6), and tested how exposure to short term (24 h) elevated temperature (+3°C) and further lowered Ω ARAG (−1 unit) affected its photosynthesis and respiration. While episodic exposure to very low Ω ARAG had only little effect on S. pistillata's physiology, short term heat stress caused a shift from net oxygen production to consumption and partial coral bleaching. Higher gross coral respiration, and lowered photosynthetic activity under episodically elevated temperature may have been the result of photoinhibition and partial coral bleaching. These findings suggest that fluctuating environmental conditions in combination with a low Ω ARAG background signal may impair basic metabolic processes in calcifying corals. In a future high-CO world short term stress could be relevant for reef ecosystem processes, and may affect the resilience of coral reefs to other external influences and effects of climate change.

body_text.text: Since the beginning of the industrial revolution, human activities have caused an increase of atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO ) from an estimated 280 ppm to about ppm in recent years (Ballantyne et al., 2012) . Pessimistic scenarios suggest that atmospheric CO 2 concentrations could reach up to 950 ppm by 2100 (IPCC, 2013) , resulting in dramatic changes of sea water carbonate chemistry (Sabine et al., 2004; The Royal Society, 2005) . Absorbed CO reacts with carbonate (CO 3 2 − ) to form carbonic acid (2 H CO 3 ), which shifts the carbonate equilibrium towards a lower calcium carbonate saturation state (Ω):
Ω ¼ Ca 2þ h i Ã CO 3 2− h i K 0

K′ is the solubility coefficient for the respective mineral phases of calcium carbonate, calcite or the less stable aragonite. Precipitation of CaCO by calcifying organisms requires Ω to be greater than one, but this becomes thermodynamically more difficult and thus increases metabolic costs as Ω decreases (Dubinsky and Stambler, 2011; The Royal Society, 2005) . Therefore, rising CO 2 levels and the resulting acidification of seawater could be a major threat to marine calcifying organisms, as it is indicated by an extensive body of research (reviewed by Fabry et al., 2008; Kleypas and Langdon, 2006; Kroeker et al., 2013) . Of the marine taxa that are impaired by elevated temperature and CO 2 concentrations, reef forming (hermatypic) corals (Schuhmacher and Zibrowius, 1985) may be particularly affected (Kroeker et al., 2010) . Supplied with photosynthetic energy from their zooxanthellae (endosymbiotic dinoflagellates, genus Symbiodinium - Dubinsky and Stambler, 2011) , hermatypic corals can precipitate large amounts of aragonite and often aggregate to complex and extensive reef structuresbiodiversity hotspots with enormous socio-economic and ecological value (Dubinsky and Stambler, 2011; Hoegh-Guldberg et al., 2007) . A reduction in Ω ARAG as a result of increased CO -influx might result in decreased reef productivity and increased coral mortality (Kleypas, 1999) , but may also lower the resilience of corals to other stressors. Elevated temperature for example can have detrimental effects on coral physiology by disturbing the symbiotic relationship between the coral host and its sensitive symbiotic algae. Under increased temperature zooxanthellae can produce reactive oxygen species (ROS) that cause oxidative damage in the host cells (Dunn et al., 2004) . To protect itself the host animal expels the symbiotic algae (Dunn et al., 2004 )a process that is also known as coral bleaching (Fitt et al., 2001) . Corals are able to expel a significant proportion of their symbionts in a matter of hours while maintaining their metabolic functions (Jones and Hoegh-Guldberg, 1998 ). However, under prolonged temperature stress, coral bleaching may increase coral respiration and reduce productivity (Hoegh-Guldberg and Smith, 1989) , decrease photosynthetic efficiency (Borell and Bischof, 2008) , and can ultimately result in tissue necrosis and death (Dunn et al., 2004) .

To investigate how gradually increased temperature and CO can affect hermatypic corals, experimental settings are usually parameterized based on differences between currently observed CO concentrations and predicted future values from various carbon emission scenarios (Kroeker et al., 2013) . However, currently observed global seawater CO concentrations are not only spatially inhomogeneous, but also show temporal variation on very short timescales (Hofmann et al., 2011) . These CO 2 fluctuations are the result of upwelling events (Feely et al., 2008; Mahadevan et al., 2011; McElhany and Busch, 2012) and diurnal patterns in community metabolism (Feely et al., 2010; Kleypas and Langdon, 2006) . Sea surface temperature may also change quickly as a function of cloud cover, precipitation and evaporation (Webster et al., 1996) . Especially coral reefs are the subject of considerable fluctuations of seawater conditions: Ω ARAG can drop by up to units within days to as low as 1.5 (Frankignoulle et al., 1996; Kleypas and Langdon, 2006; Ohde and van Woesik, 1999) , and temperature can increase by up to 3°C per day (Castillo and Helmuth, 2005; Jones and Hoegh-Guldberg, 1998; Putnam and Edmunds, 2011) . These intense short-term changes of environmental conditions could have the potential to complicate our understanding of how corals respond to the effects of climate change (Hendriks et al., 2010; Kroeker et al., 2010) , but little is known how high frequency dynamics of temperature and Ω ARAG may affect the physiology of hermatypic corals.

As outlined above, extensive research suggests that elevated temperature and lowered Ω ARAG as a result of global climate change are a threat to hermatypic corals. However, temperature and Ω ARAG in coral reefs can change rapidly (Kleypas and Langdon, 2006) , a phenomenon that is likely to be amplified by strong effects of global change in the tropics (IPCC, 2013; The Royal Society, 2005) . In a future low aragonite environment, these naturally occurring fluctuations in temperature and Ω ARAG may have a considerable impact on coral physiology, as they may add up to a low Ω ARAG background signal. To investigate how coral physiology reacts to naturally occurring abiotic fluctuations in addition to a low Ω ARAG background signal, we acclimated colonies of the hermatypic coral Stylophora pistillata to low Ω ARAG and exposed them to elevated temperature and further lowered Ω ARAG ; each separately and in combination. During 24 hour laboratory experiments (12 h light:12 h dark) photosynthetic rates, respiration, and signs of bleaching were recorded. Ω ARAG was adjusted based on values of currently observed ranges of daily fluctuations and on the level of predicted future values in tropical latitudes (Kleypas, 1999) . We discuss how our results compare to the findings of other studies with different time frames, and list possible mechanisms that may cause shifts in coral metabolism as a result of rapid changes in temperature and Ω ARAG .

The zooxanthellate scleractinian coral S. pistillata (Esper, 1797) forms branched colonies in shallow reef environments throughout the Indo-Pacific region (Hoeksema et al., 2014) , where it grows in several clades that show substantial variation in the phenotype and symbiotic composition (Keshavmurthy et al., 2013) . This particular coral species was used because it may be particularly threatened from climate change: its relatively thin coral tissue (Bhagooli and Hidaka, 2004) and disadvantageous light scattering properties (Enrquez et al., 2005) may negatively influence resistance to multiple stressors. Moreover, S. pistillata is well represented in scientific literature, which allows for comparison to findings from previous experiments that used similar stressors. In November 2009, 10 coral colonies of S. pistillata's pink phenotype were acquired from DeJong Marine Life Corp., Spijksesteeg 2a, 4212KG in Spijk, Netherlands, and transported to the Leibniz Center for Tropical Marine Ecology (ZMT) in Bremen, Germany, where all experiments were conducted.

The experimental setup consisted of two functional units: a mesocosm tank where the corals were maintained, and an intermittent flow respirometer system in which seawater temperature and Ω ARAG were manipulated and the corals' metabolic response quantified. The mesocosm tank system was filled with artificial seawater that had been contained in the tank for several years to maintain tropical calcifying corals and also contained other coral species, benthic fauna and reef fishes to simulate a near nature environment. Two weeks after colonies of S. pistillata were placed inside the mesocosm, Ω ARAG was gradually reduced by controlled inflow of CO 2 (Biogon). Ω ARAG was used to parameterize manipulations in carbonate chemistry for this study, because it seems to be more closely associated with physiological processes of calcifying organisms than just pH or CO 2 content (Hofmann et al., 2011) . Between November 2009 and January 2010, Ω ARAG decreased from approx. 3 to 1.63 ± 0.13. During this time only one colony of S. pistillata died, while the nine colonies that successfully acclimated to a low Ω ARAG environment appeared healthy (morphology, color, polyp extension) and showed obvious skeletal growth. Therefore it was assumed that the lowered Ω ARAG value was tolerable by the corals, and that the conditions in the mesocosm were applicable as the experimental control.

In the mesocosm, metal halide lamps (Aquamedic) provided an irradiance of approx. 200 μmol quanta cm −2 −s 1 in a light cycle with 12 h of light and a 12 h of darkness. To ensure proper coral nutrition, Artemia spp. brine shrimp were fed to the colonies every three days, since a lack of heterotrophic nutrition can significantly alter photosynthesis and respiration in corals (Borell and Bischof, 2008; Hoogenboom et al., 2012) . Salinity, temperature and pH were monitored twice a day (WTW 350i) with a temperature/conductivity probe and a Clark-type electrode (WTW), calibrated with certified TRIS buffers. Total alkalinity (TA) was adjusted with a carbonate reactor that provided HCO 3 − and Ca + ions. TA was controlled once a week with acidbase titration (titration stand, Schott) that was calibrated using a certified sea-water standard (Hach). With pH and TA; Ω ARAG , pCO 2 , HCO 3 − , CO 3 2 − and CO 2 aq could be calculated using the program CO2SYS (Pierrot et al., 2006) . After establishing a low Ω ARAG , environmental conditions in the mesocosm were maintained with high accuracy (Table 1 , mesocosm) during the following two months, in which all experimental trials were conducted.

Single coral colonies were moved from the mesocosm to the respirometer system, where they were exposed in 24 h experiments either to low ambient Ω ARAG conditions that were established in the mesocosm (hereafter referred to as control), elevated temperature, low Ω ARAG , and elevated temperature in combination with low Ω ARAG (Table 1) . Specific parameters were derived from adding observed maximum ranges for daily fluctuations of seawater around coral reefs, where temperature can change by up to 3°C and Ω ARAG by up to 1 unit (Frankignoulle et al., 1996; Kleypas and Langdon, 2006) , to the low Ω ARAG conditions that were maintained in the mesocosm. To establish these conditions for the respective experiments, seawater was taken out of the mesocosm, filtered with a bacterial filter (Acro Pak 1000 0.8/0.2 μm, Pall Corporation), and filled into the respirometer. Inside the respirometer the seawater was then either heated to 30°C or gassed with CO to reduce pH corresponding to an Ω ARAG of approx 0.6, or both for the temperature-Ω ARAG -combination experiment. For the control filtered, but otherwise untreated mesocosm seawater was used. After the seawater was manipulated according to the target conditions, the coral colony was placed inside the respirometer and the experiment was started.

During the experiments the corals were visually checked for signs of bleaching. After each light and each dark phase at the end of the experiment, the proportion of bleached coral surface was estimated as "no bleaching, below 25%, 25-50%, above 50%". At the end of an experiment the used colony was immediately returned to the mesocosm for recovery. Because not enough corals were available for a fully factorial design, the colonies had to be used for multiple measurements. Out of all nine colonies, five were first used for the measurements under control conditions and four were first used for the low Ω ARAG treatment. Four coral colonies that were previously used for the control measurements had to be used again in the elevated temperature treatment. For the combination experiment one colony from the control measurements and three corals from the low Ω ARAG treatment were used. There were at least three weeks between each use, which has been observed to be sufficient for S. pistillata's recovery from short term stress (Hoegh-Guldberg and Smith, 1989) . During the time between experiments coral health was assessed by checking polyp extension, coloration, and growth estimation. The effects of coral colony identity and previous use in a low Ω ARAG stress or a control measurement were also statistically tested.

Coral photosynthesis and respiration were measured inside an intermittent flow respirometer (Forstner, 1983 ) that was modified by (Zimmermann and Kunzmann, 2001) (Fig. 1) . In a closed compartment the change of O 2 concentration as a result of production or consumption by a coral colony was measured in recurrent (intermittent) periods. During a measurement period, seawater was constantly pumped through a closed water cycle that consisted of a respiration chamber where the coral was placed, a temperature probe (PT100, Driessen & Kern) and an O sensor (Oxi 340i & Clark Type Cellox 325, both WTW). A cogwheel pump ensured adequate mixing inside the respiration chamber and a steady water flow against the sensors. The change of O 2 saturation over time was recorded until saturation within the closed cycle reached a pre-adjusted upper threshold at 120% or lower threshold at 70%. When either of these thresholds were reached, a computer control unit (DT9803, Data Translation), automatically opened a valve and flushed the measurement cycle with seawater from a reservoir tank that had an O 2 saturation of approx 100%. When the O 2 sensor inside the measurement cycle detected a saturation of between 90% and 105%, the valve closed the cycle and a new measurement period was initiated.

The reservoir tank was coupled with a pH and temperature computer (Aquamedic) that controlled heating elements and CO -inflow. Every time the closed cycle was flushed to adjust the O 2 saturation, it received seawater that was heated or enriched with CO 2 according to the desired treatment conditions (Fig. 1 ). The closed cycle and the reservoir were located within a large water container that buffered temperature fluctuations. A metal halide lamp similar to the ones used for the mesocosmsetup was installed to create an irradiance of approx. 200 μmol quanta cm −2 s −1 above the respirometer (12 h:12 h light/dark phases). Prior to the measurements, all benthic and epifaunal organisms were removed from the coral and its concrete socket, and all water bearing parts of the respirometer were mechanically cleaned, purified with 90% ethanol and rinsed. Before and after each trial, a baseline measurement of the system without the coral was performed to create an experimental blank which was subtracted from the imminent measurement, and to check for bacterial respiration.

From the recorded temperature and the changes in O saturation over time, production and consumption rates could be calculated. The resolution of the control unit was 10,000 measurements per minute. Outliers were automatically excluded and a mean value per minute calculated. Photosynthetic and respiration rates were normalized to coral surface, which was quantified with the advanced geometry approach (Naumann et al., 2009) . General linear mixed models (GLMM) were applied to test for an effect of Ω Arag and temperature on coral metabolism in the light and dark phases, and to test if repeated use of the colonies affected the response to the treatments. One model for each light period used net O 2 production or consumption during the light phase as the response, elevated temperature or low Ω ARAG as categorical fixed effects, and colony identity and the number of times the colony was used for a previous treatment as random effects (GLMM: light/dark oxygen flux = response variable, treatments = fixed effect, random effects = colony identity + previous use). A Tukey post-hoc analysis was used to check if rates were significantly different between the treatments. Normal distribution and homogeneity of variances were tested visually using Q-Q and residual plots. Analyses were conducted using the lme4 package in the R language (v 3.0.2 -R Core Team, 2013).

Temperature and Ω ARAG were manipulated in the respirometer with high accuracy, although there were some inconsistencies in the low Table 1 Seawater conditions during maintenance and experimental trials. In the two months of the experimental phase, S. pistillata was maintained in a mesocosm tank with an Ω ARAG of 1.63 ± 0.13. All seawater parameters in the mesocosm tank were measured twice a day except for TA, which was measured once a week. In the respirometer, photosynthesis and respiration were measured for five colonies under control conditions (=conditions in the mesocosm); four colonies under low Ω arag , four colonies under elevated temperature, and four colonies under combined low Ω arag and elevated temperature. During the experiments, salinity, pH and TA were measured at the beginning, in the middle and at the end of every trial; temperature was recorded continuously by the respirometer.

Control ( Zimmermann and Kunzmann (2001) ). S. pistillata's O 2 -balance, i.e. photosynthesis or respiration, was captured by measuring changes of O saturation inside a sealed water compartment (closed cycle). Between periods of measurements O saturation was adjusted by controlled (intermittent) inflow of seawater from a reservoir with oxygenated seawater (100%). The seawater in the reservoir tank was heated or gassed with CO according to the current treatment. Fig. 2 . Accuracy of experimental treatments. Left panel shows mean temperature ±SD measured inside the respirometer under control Ω ARAG ( ) and low Ω ARAG (▼). Right panel shows mean Ω ARAG ± SD measured inside the respirometer under control temperature ( ) and elevated temperature (▲). A significant deviation occurred during the low Ω ARAG (=control temperature) treatment, in which mean temperature was approx. 1.2°C higher than the targeted control level, and mean Ω ARAG 0.44 higher than the targeted low Ω ARAG level.

Ω ARAG treatment (Fig. 2) . At the time the trials with this treatment were conducted, a leak in the carbonate reactor increased TA in the mesocosm seawater that was used for this treatment from a mean of 1381 ± 103 μmol kg −1 to 1788 ± 136 μmol kg −1 (Table 1) . This was discovered too late and because the pH computer was calibrated for lower TA, Ω ARAG was not reduced by one unit to the target level of approx 0.6, but to 1.01 ± 0.19 instead. Furthermore, a programming error in the temperature control unit resulted in an average water temperature that was about 1.2°C higher in the low Ω ARAG treatment than the targeted 26.69 ± 0.29°C in the control. A temperature of 27.9 ± 0.18°C is considered to be within S. pistillata's range of tolerance (Jones and Hoegh-Guldberg, 1998) , but because the coral colonies used in this study were acclimated to a temperature of 26.69 ± 0.29 it may already have affected their metabolism. However, as the adjusted conditions for the low Ω ARAG treatment were not inherently flawed and still relatively close to the range of the targeted values, the measurements from these experiments were used for analysis. All nine colonies of S. pistillata survived the 24 h exposure to control conditions from the mesocosm, elevated temperature, low Ω ARAG and the combination of both stressors. In the light, the corals' photosynthetic rates were 0.14 ± 0.05 μmol O 2 cm −2 h −1 in the control and 0.06 ± 0.04 μmol O 2 cm −2 h −1 under low Ω Arag ; both different with marginal significance (P = 0.08). Elevated temperature, alone and in combination with low Ω ARAG caused S. pistillata to consume O with a rate of 0.09 ± 0.16 μmol cm −2 h −1 and 0.135 ± 0.13 μmol cm −2 h −1 , respectively. These consumption rates were not significantly different from each other (P = 0.04). Across all treatments in the light phase, elevated temperature had a highly significant effect on S. pistillata (GLMM, P = 0.001), causing net O consumption, whereas low Ω Arag had no effect on S. pistillata's O 2 balance (GLMM, P = 0.31). There was no interactive effect of low Ω ARAG and elevated temperature (GLMM, P = 0.733), and also no influence of colony identity (GLMM, P = 0.8) and previous use of a coral colony (GLMM, P = 0.4) as random effects on photosynthesis or respiration in the light.

In the dark, respiration rates ranged from 0.44 ± 0.17 μmol O 2 cm −2h −1 in the control to a maximum O consumption of 0.7 ± 0.17 μmol O 2 cm −2 h −1 in the combination treatment. In the treatments with low Ω Arag or elevated temperature alone, respiration rates were 0.58 ± 0.18 and 0.58 ± 0.07 μmol O cm −2 h −1 ; both not significantly different (P N 0.001). In the dark, both low Ω ARAG and temperature had a significant impact on coral respiration (GLMM, P = 0.047 and P = 0.053, respectively), but did not interactively affect S. pistillata's O 2 balance (GLMM, P = 0.4). There were no influences of colony identity and previous use of a coral colony on respiration, as the non-significance of random effects indicates (GLMM, P = 0.5 and P = 0.3).

Beside changes in S. pistillata's O 2 balance, partial losses of zooxanthellae and mucus production were observed for several colonies. Coral bleaching mostly occurred under heat stress: no signs of bleaching were visible during the control measurements and, except for one coral colony, under low Ω ARAG alone (Fig. 3) . Under elevated temperature, five out of eight coral colonies used in the single and the combination treatment indicated slight signs of bleaching (b 25%) after the light phase. At the end of the experiments, three coral colonies showed slight bleaching, one colony showed moderate bleaching (25-50%), two colonies were severely bleached (N50%), and two colonies remained unbleached (Fig. 3) .

In this study we investigated how the metabolism of the hermatypic coral S. pistillata that was acclimated to a future low Ω ARAG scenario was affected by episodic increases in temperature and further lowered Ω ARAG . Photosynthesis, respiration, and signs of bleaching were recorded for nine coral colonies during 24 h experiments (12 h light:12 h dark). While low Ω ARAG had no effect on S. pistillata's photosynthesis during the light phase, elevated temperature significantly affected coral metabolism and caused a shift from net O 2 production to consumption and partial bleaching. Dark respiration was affected by both Fig. 3 . O -production and consumption of S. pistillata under control conditions, low Ω ARAG , elevated temperature and the combination of low Ω ARAG and elevated temperature. O 2 balance is shown as mean ± SD ( ) of all replicate coral colonies used for a treatment. The same data is split up by response of a single coral in the light phase ( ) and in the dark phase ( ). Gray filling indicates estimated proportion of coral bleaching observed after the light and dark phase. elevated temperature and low Ω ARAG . Our findings suggest that under low Ω ARAG conditions, short term changes in temperature and carbonate chemistry may be physiologically relevant to hermatypic corals.

Ω ARAG did not have a significant impact on the net photosynthetic rate of S. pistillata. Merely a trend for reduced O production was evident, possibly due to the slightly elevated temperature level in this treatment (Fig. 3) . According to (Al-Horani, 2005 ) the adjusted temperature of 27.9 ± 0.18°C is on the upper end of an optimum range for gross photosynthesis. Net photosynthesis, however, should already be declining due to elevated light respiration, which is consistent with the observed trend. During the dark phase, S. pistillata's respiration rate was increased under low Ω ARAG , which could be due to higher metabolic activity of the coral host. This is in agreement with other long (Marubini et al., 2008; Schneider and Erez, 2006) , medium (Leclercq et al., 2002; Takahashi and Kurihara, 2012) and short term-studies (Agostini et al., 2013) that showed similar results in laboratory or field experiments with different hermatypic corals: lowered Ω ARAG by lowered pH did not affect photosynthesis in any of these studies, regardless of the used time frame.

This suggests an active physiological mechanism that the coral host uses to protect itself against disadvantageous conditions of the seawater carbonate system, which can be enabled promptly. Agostini et al. (2013) and Al-Horani and Al-Moghrabi (2003) detected changes in the diffusive boundary layer (DBL) of the coral, identifying it as a possible aspect of the protective mechanism. Through the DBL the coral-polyps can mitigate seawater-pH to more favorable conditions, both under normal and high CO 2 , by high photosynthetic rates and the consumption of CO 2 . Elevated net photosynthesis rate under elevated CO 2 was also observed by Langdon and Atkinson (2005) who used an outdoor laboratory setup. The resulting higher irradiance levels could explain this increase, as opposed to the lack of effect with lower irradiance featured in this study (approx. 200 μmol photons cm − 2 s −1 ). The hypothesis that scleractinian corals can sustain basic physiological mechanisms like photosynthesis independent of the duration of a CO 2 stress event is also supported by Fine and Tchernov (2007) , who observed a reduction of the coral skeleton but an increase in polyp biomass over a longer period of time.

Elevated temperature had a highly significant effect on the metabolism of S. pistillata: the recorded negative net O 2 balance indicates that coral respiration exceeded gross photosynthesis. Because the respirometer used in this study was not able to distinguish between photosynthesis and respiration, this hypothesis stems from the observed increased dark respiration rate, and similar findings from several short-term studies (Al-Horani, 2005; Nordemar et al., 2003; Nyström et al., 2001) . A strong effect of temperature has also been observed in previous studies that used long (Rodolfo-Metalpa et al., 2010) and medium (Hoogenboom et al., 2012; Middlebrook et al., 2010) exposure of different coral species to heat. This suggests that the effects of temperature stress on photo-physiological processes within a hermatypic coral are mostly negative and may not depend on the duration of the stress exerted. However, in none of the aforementioned studies elevated temperature resulted in a shift to net O 2 consumption, as observed in this study. While some variation in response may stem from experimental conditions like irradiance and feeding, coral responses seem to vary with the studied species and the organisms' respective "temperature-history" (Castillo and Helmuth, 2005; Flores-Ramírez and Liñán Cabello, 2007) . In this study, acclimation to moderate ambient temperatures of 26.69 ± 0.29 in the mesocosm could explain the observed strong negative reaction to a temperature increase of 3°C. The studies cited above acclimated the corals to higher temperatures and used higher irradiance, which could have resulted in higher production rates and thus a positive O 2 balance.

These observed reaction to elevated temperature confirm the notion that S. pistillata may be among the corals that are relatively sensitive to environmental stress (Bhagooli and Hidaka, 2004; Fitt et al., 2009) . This may be due to a relatively thin tissue thickness (Enrquez et al., 2005) , with lower temperature buffering capacity, and a skeletal morphology that facilitates high in hospite irradiance (Fitt et al., 2009) . Beside species specific effects there are general physiological consequences of elevated temperature for a zooxanthellate coral. Overall more O is consumed by the host through oxidative phosphorylation, because the coral becomes more active with higher temperature and therefore requires more ATP (Al-Horani, 2005 ). Furthermore, dynamic and chronic photoinhibition can occur during short-and long-term (Bhagooli and Hidaka, 2004) temperature stress and cause a dramatic reduction of the efficiency of the photosystem II to prevent over-reduction at the electron-transportsystem (Bhagooli and Hidaka, 2004; Jones and Hoegh-Guldberg, 1998) . Other effects of photoinhibition are the release of excess energy as additional heat, which can additionally compromise the host, and the formation of ROS. The coral host tolerates these harmful byproducts of the photosystem-electron-transfer up to a threshold (Downs et al., 2002) . At a certain ROS concentration in the host, the symbionts are expelled to prevent cellular damage within the holobiont (Flores-Ramírez and Liñán Cabello, 2007; Jones and Hoegh-Guldberg, 1998) , leading to coral bleaching. This process is reversible if the heat stress ceases soon enough and host tissue is not damaged beyond repair (Dunn et al., 2004) . Expulsion seems to be a last resort in protecting the coral host from excessive heat, but, as results from this and other cited studies suggest (Agostini et al., 2013; Nordemar et al., 2003) , may be carried out at any point of time. This could be an explanation for the observed partial bleaching during the elevated temperature treatments. These processesphotoinhibition, and expulsion of O 2 -producing symbionts in combination with elevated host respirationcould have led to the observed net respiration during the light phase and elevated respiration during the dark phase.

There was no significant interaction of temperature and Ω ARAG , and the respiration rate in the combined treatment was not significantly different from O 2 consumption in the elevated temperature treatment. The increased dark respiration suggests that light respiration exceeds gross photosynthesis and causes net O consumption. This reaction was not expected and also differs from similar short term studies (Agostini et al., 2013; Reynaud et al., 2003) . We anticipated that elevated CO concentration would meet the increased CO demand caused by elevated temperature on the photosynthetic rate by increasing the concentration gradient between seawater and the CO 2 -binding components of the photosystems within the zooxanthellae. However, since increased CO 2 in the Ω ARAG treatment did not induce elevated photosynthesis, this hypothesis can be rejected. Elevated temperature may cause photoinhibition and the expulsion of symbionts, causing a disruption in the energy transfer system and increased respiration. The statistical analysis revealed that only temperature had a significant effect, both on photosynthesis and respiration, and therefore seems to be the predominant factor in the combined stress experiment.
body_text.section: Response to combined lowered aragonite and elevated temperature

body_text.text: Many studies that investigated how climate change affects reef building corals have reported negative effects of water temperature and carbonate chemistry on coral metabolism. Still, little is known about how a highly variable environment interacts with the slowly progressing effects of climate change, and how this might affect the reef community. This study may provide a first insight in how the physiology of hermatypic coral that has acclimated to a low Ω ARAG environment responds to episodic heat stress and further lowered Ω ARAG . While very low Ω ARAG had only little effect on S. pistillata's physiology, short term heat stress induced a significant metabolic reaction in S. pistillata. The observed shift to net O 2 consumption under elevated temperature could be due to higher gross coral respiration, and lowered photosynthetic activity as a consequence of partial coral bleaching. The expulsion of zooxanthellae and photoinhibition may be the cause for this metabolic depression.

Competing hermatypic corals have different ranges of tolerance for temperature (Bhagooli and Hidaka, 2004) and Ω ARAG (Edmunds et al., 2012; Kleypas and Langdon, 2006) , which can serve as structuring factors for coral assemblages within a reef community (Blackford, 2010; Hoegh-Guldberg et al., 2007) . The findings from this study suggest that episodic stress in addition to a low Ω ARAG background signal can impair basic metabolic processes in S. pistillata, a species with a relatively narrow range of tolerance. As a consequence, species that react heavily to episodic stress may also have a lower resilience to other external influences and multiple stressors. As global climate change gradually alters the marine environment, diurnal events of heat stress and very low Ω ARAG as a result of upwelling or community metabolism may affect how reef building corals acclimate to future conditions. Species with low tolerance to these events might be displaced earlier and the resulting shifts in reef community composition (Widdicombe and Spicer, 2008) may in turn affect reef ecosystem function and stability (Dubinsky and Stambler, 2011; Hoegh-Guldberg et al., 2007) . We argue that environmental stress during short timescales can be physiologically and ecologically relevant for hermatypic corals and may influence how coral reefs adapt to future climate changes.

back_matter.text: Jana Holler contributed substantially to this project, which would not have been possible without her help. We thank Christian Brandt, Stefanie Broehl and Epiphane Yeyi for their technical assistance. We are also grateful to the helpful comments from two reviewers that greatly improved a previous version of this paper.
